 f you grew up as a younger brother in a houseful of boys, you have probably lost count of the ways your big brothers shaped your life. Now a new study suggests that if you're also gay, they may have had a role in that too.
 
 Since the 1990s, many social psychologists have concluded that gays represent about 3% of all males-although that's a much debated figure. Others put it as low as 1% or as high as 10%. Those who subscribe to the 3% figure believe they have documented an interesting wrinkle: among boys with one older brother, the figure goes up to about 4%; two older brothers tick it up to 5%; and with three or more, it tops out at about 6%. What nobody could answer is, Why?
 
 Last week psychologist Anthony Bogaert of Brock University in Ontario, Canada, provided some clues from a study of 944 men. Some were raised with biological brothers or stepbrothers; others had biological brothers but were raised apart. In almost no case did homosexuality seem to correlate with stepbrothers living under the same roof. It was only the existence of older biological brothers-whether or not they were raised together-that influenced younger brothers' sexuality. 
 http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1209914,00.html
 
 Another obvious indicator that GENETICS plays a part.
 After all, there is no rational reason why the influence would be different between genetic and step-brothers if there is no genetic influence.
 Science 101. Separate and test the variables individually.

Gay couples can't have biological kids together. So if homosexuality is genetic, why hasn't it died out?
 
 A study published last week in PLoS One tackles the question. It starts with four curious patterns. First, male homosexuality occurs at a low but stable frequency in a wide range of societies. Second, the female relatives of gay men produce children at a higher rate than other women do. Third, among these female relatives, those related to the gay man's mother produce children at a higher rate than do those related to his father. Fourth, among the man's male relatives, homosexuality is more common in those related to his mother than in those related to his father.
 
 Can genes account for these patterns? To find out, the authors posit several possible mechanisms and compute their effects over time. They conclude that only one theory fits the data. The theory is called "sexually antagonistic selection." It holds that a gene can be reproductively harmful to one sex as long as it's helpful to the other. The gene for male homosexuality persists because it promotes-and is passed down through-high rates of procreation among gay men's mothers, sisters, and aunts.
 
 This theory doesn't account for female homosexuality, which another new study (reviewed in Human Nature last week) attributes to nongenetic factors. It also doesn't account for environmental or prenatal chemical factors in male homosexuality, such as the correlation between a man's probability of homosexuality and the number of boys previously gestated in his mother's womb. But it does explain the high similarity of sexual orientation between identical twins, as well as patterns of homosexuality in families. It's also plausible because sexually antagonistic selection has been found in other species. And many scientists who think environmental and prenatal factors influence homosexuality also believe that genes play a role.
 
 The authors note that according to their computations, the theory implies some testable predictions. One such prediction can be checked against existing data. The prediction is that on average, if you're a straight man, the reproductive pattern among your aunts will reverse the pattern seen among aunts of gay men. That is, your paternal aunts will produce children at a higher rate than your maternal aunts will. The authors check this prediction against the available data. Sure enough, it holds up.
 
 I don't know to what extent this theory will end up explaining male homosexuality. But its emergence threatens to change our thinking about gay men in several important ways.
 
 First, it implies natural limits to homosexuality. You don't need to worry that gay teachers or television characters will "convert" hordes of boys. Sexually antagonistic selection is self-limiting and impervious to postnatal cultural factors. The authors' computations show no scenario in which male homosexuality spreads throughout a population.
 
 Second, by the same token, you can't culturally eradicate the gay minority. It's sustained by genetics and natural selection.
 
 Third, if the authors are correct, we're not really talking about genes for homosexuality. We're talking about genes for "androphilia," i.e., attraction to men. The importance of the genes lies in what they do not to men but to women, by increasing reproductive output so powerfully that these women compensate for the reduced output among their male relatives. You can't isolate gay men as a puzzle or problem anymore. You have to see them as part of a bigger, stronger, enduring phenomenon.
 
 Fourth, this larger phenomenon can't be dismissed as a disorder. The study's press release concludes that "homosexuality should not be viewed as a detrimental trait (due to the reduced male fecundity it entails), but, rather, should be considered within the wider evolutionary framework of a characteristic with gender-specific benefits."
 
 Fifth, the benefits aren't really confined to women. They protect society as a whole. The authors' computations indicate that as a society's birthrate falls, female carriers of androphilic genes account for a larger share of the output. In short, the genes provide a "buffer effect" against extinction.
 
 The study's lead author, Andrea Camperio Ciani of the University of Padova, sees these ramifications as a happy ending. "This is an example where the results of scientific research can have important social implications," he tells LiveScience. "You have all this antagonism against homosexuality because they say it's against nature because it doesn't lead to reproduction. We found out this is not true because homosexuality is just one of the consequences of strategies for making females more fecund."
 
 But the word consequence suggests a sixth, less happy implication: How would gay men see themselves and be regarded in a society that understood their condition as a side effect of female evolution? Would male androphilia be treated like sickle-cell anemia-the unfortunate cost of a genetic mutation that's beneficial in other people? We medicate sickle-cell anemia. Would we medicate homosexuality?
 
 I don't know, and neither does Dr. Camperio Ciani. Science, like culture and politics, has its happy moments. But don't mistake them for endings.

 Thanks for posting this article about an actual study which resulted in a model for homosexulaity. It's instructive to realise from subsequent posts that those who object to homosexuality simply ignored it! Par for the course.
 
 I think a couple of points from it could do with repetition:
 
 
First, it implies natural limits to homosexuality. You don't need to worry that gay teachers or television characters will "convert" hordes of boys. Sexually antagonistic selection is self-limiting and impervious to postnatal cultural factors. The authors' computations show no scenario in which male homosexuality spreads throughout a population.
 
 Second, by the same token, you can't culturally eradicate the gay minority. It's sustained by genetics and natural selection.
 
 Third, if the authors are correct, we're not really talking about genes for homosexuality. We're talking about genes for "androphilia," i.e., attraction to men. The importance of the genes lies in what they do not to men but to women, by increasing reproductive output so powerfully that these women compensate for the reduced output among their male relatives. You can't isolate gay men as a puzzle or problem anymore. You have to see them as part of a bigger, stronger, enduring phenomenon.
 
 Fourth, this larger phenomenon can't be dismissed as a disorder. The study's press release concludes that "homosexuality should not be viewed as a detrimental trait (due to the reduced male fecundity it entails), but, rather, should be considered within the wider evolutionary framework of a characteristic with gender-specific benefits."
 
 Fifth, the benefits aren't really confined to women. They protect society as a whole. The authors' computations indicate that as a society's birthrate falls, female carriers of androphilic genes account for a larger share of the output. In short, the genes provide a "buffer effect" against extinction.

 Here's an abstract:
 
 Fraternal birth order and the maternal immune hypothesis of male homosexuality.
 
 Horm Behav. 2001 Sep;40(2):105-14
 
 Blanchard R.
 Centre for Addiction and Mental Health-Clarke Site, Department of Psychiatry, Faculty of Medicine, University of Toronto, 250 College Street, Toronto, Ontario M5T 1R8, Canada. Ray_Blanchard@camh.net
 
 In men, sexual orientation correlates with an individual's number of older brothers, each additional older brother increasing the odds of homosexuality by approximately 33%. It has been hypothesized that this fraternal birth order effect reflects the progressive immunization of some mothers to Y-linked minor histocompatibility antigens (H-Y antigens) by each succeeding male fetus and the concomitantly increasing effects of such maternal immunization on the future sexual orientation of each succeeding male fetus. According to this hypothesis, anti-H-Y antibodies produced by the mother pass through the placental barrier to the fetus and affect aspects of sexual differentiation in the fetal brain. This explanation is consistent with a variety of evidence, including the apparent irrelevance of older sisters to the sexual orientation of later born males, the probable involvement of H-Y antigen in the development of sex-typical traits, and the detrimental effects of immunization of female mice to H-Y antigen on the reproductive performance of subsequent male offspring. The maternal immune hypothesis might also explain the recent finding that heterosexual males with older brothers weigh less at birth than heterosexual males with older sisters and homosexual males with older brothers weigh even less than heterosexual males with older brothers. Copyright 2001 Academic Press.
 
 PMID: 11534970 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

I also wonder if anyone has considered an epigenetic hypothesis for homosexuality. Maybe homosexuality isn't genetic per se, but is governed by how genes are expressed.
 
 For example, much of early embryonic development is known to be governed by the biochemical gradients established inside an ovum by the mother, long before conception. Also, males and females use genetic imprinting in sperm and ova to determine which genes will be expressed, when, and how much.
 
 It could be that sexual orientation is, in part, a consequence of genetic imprinting, or perhaps by pre-fertilisation maternal manipulation of the development of a fertilised egg.
 
 I don't really know if such hypotheses have been considered, let alone tested yet, but they can't be discounted a priori.  Yes, it is, but remember that even though gays are made naturally, that doesn't address the value question of whether being gay is good for an individual.
 
 Take, for example, the sexually antagonistic selection hypothesis posted earlier. It postulates that what we have is a "gene for" androphilia or fecundity in females, which has the additional effect of making some men gay. If this is correct, then it's easy to explain how it might have been selected for, why it persists in the population, and why it's better to have a few gay males than fewer productive females.
 
 However, this is, in essence, a form of group selection hypothesis -- it claims that having some homosexuals is good for the population because of the adjunct increase in fecundity. However, that doesn't mean that homosexuality is good for the affected male individual, nor does it mean that it shouldn't be expressed, treated or punished. That's a cultural decision, and not a biological one.
 
 An analogy is the gene that causes sickle cell anaemia. While it isn't really a "gene for" sickle cell anaemia -- it's more of a "gene against" malaria -- and although its existence is good for individuals in malaria zones, it is actually debilitating for individuals, which is why we seek treatment for it.
 
 I just point this out to counteract the view that having a natural explanation for diversity in human sexuality doesn't automatically mean that all expressions of sexuality are good. What is natural is not necessarily good, as though of us who correct our natural myopia with lenses know. We still have to make value judgements irrespective of our biology.
 
 Of course, this keeps the ball in the court of the bigots to demonstrate why being gay is bad for the individual. And spamming the board with bible verses as our Archie does in support of religious bigotry is not a very good answer.

Gay lifestyle dangerous 
 Published: May 28, 2008 
 Paul Sikora ("Anti-gay arguments spurious," Readers' Forum, May 27) shouldn't need the Bible to understand the dangers of the gay lifestyle. Statistics alone should confirm to any mature adult the necessity of protecting traditional marriage as the foundation of a healthy society. There are currently (worldwide) 30.8 million adults and 2.5 million children infected with the AIDS virus. In 2007, 2.5 million people became infected with AIDS. Some 420,000 children in that year were infected with the virus. In 2007, 2.1 million people died from AIDS. By the end of 2005, there were 15.2 million AIDS orphans worldwide.
 Statistics support the Bible's warning as well as that of modern prophets, that the gay lifestyle is a bad mistake. Legislation in favor of gay marriage legitimizes a lifestyle in the minds of gender-confused youths who need a clear message that it is wrong, that it causes misery, that it destroys life, and that it costs billions of medical dollars. We need legislation that promotes and rewards those who choose the lifestyle of marriage between one man and one woman, a lifestyle that has never caused any catastrophic disease.
 
 Marcia Ogden
 Provo

 You certainly can hold to any personal religious view that you want to, no doubt. So can we all. 
 
 Here's the sticky part, though. I know quite a few Christians who say their faith calls on them to evangelize. For some, evangelizing means telling gay people that we are going to hell if we don't renounce our alleged "sin" and somehow turn heterosexual. 
 
 I am most happy to let people practice their faith as they choose. But when they choose to stick their faith in my face in the form of this kind of evangelizing, I feel free to evangelize back to them. That's just free speech. Done respectfully, it can be valuable dialogue. 
 
 Beyond that, many churches and religious bodies do seek to spread their religious beliefs into the public arena, and churches do take stands on hotly debated social issues. Indeed, the main opponents of equal treatment under the law for gay people are religious organizations, and they put a lot of money and organizing into trying to deny us equal treatment under the law. When religious institutions enter the public square, they are fair game for robust criticism. 
 
 In another thread, you said the Supreme Court is not beyond reproach. Neither are the churches and religious organizations that push for laws that would deny equal rights to gay people. They should not be immune from criticism simply because they are religious institutions. If they are going to press for the passage of laws, then they cannot hide behind the frocks of the ministry or priesthood and claim that people must not criticize them. It's our duty as citizens to criticize them when they are wrong. 
 
 I apply this standard to my own church as well. We are active in pushing for certain laws and for changes in the public arena, as part of our social justice work. For example, we gathered signatures on a referendum petitition that ended up successfully raising the minimum wage in Ohio. We are active in opposing the death penalty. Our church also works FOR same-sex marriage rights. We are not immune to criticism, and we expect it, as we are a socially active church body. (We do not work in the electoral political arena, of course, as that is out of bounds for a church non-profit. We are completely non-partisan, and our work is on issues, not on behalf of candidates.)

 I think that's fine, and would never say that one should never criticize a church or religious group. The approach I often see here against churches is that they shouldn't take a stand on this at all. In other words, they should be a silent church. But we don't tell anyone else that. Part of the basis for that is that some seem to have a wide view of what constitutes hate speech when it comes to statements by churches and religious groups.  Well in the case of what happened with the incident on the ship I was on I can describe it in detail maybe to give a better insight into why I am so adamant on the rights of gays and people in general. Mind you this is extremely painful for me to remeber and dwell on so it is very hard for me to type this.
 
 On december 28th 2007 I had returned from holiday stand down from california for 5 days. I spent a great christmas with my family and had just comissioned the navys newest warship the USS Mesa Verde only 3 weeks before. 6 months of hard toil from our crew to undue the damage and setbacks from katrina was a great toil upon our 500 man crew. We worked from 3 am to 8 at night monday through sunday and even on thanksgiving to get the ship qualified and inscected by Navsea. needless to say we passed with flying colors. 
 
 Anyways, I was sleeping in my bottom rack and had to get up very early for duty section turnover. Mind you most of the crew was gone on new years stand down as half the crew got christmas the other half new years off. As a result I was the only person in the berthing at the time cause everyone else was on watch at the time. Then 4 of my shipmates came in reeking of alcohol and sluring and cursing and cause a riot. So I asked them to be quiet cause I had to get up the next day.
 
 next thing I knew I was being dragged feet first out of my rack on the cold hard deck of the ship. I was stood up and slammed against the lockers next to my bunk and held there by 2 guys. One went to keep a watch on the berthing door to make sure no one came in. The other proceeded to spew gay insults and racial remarks at me and then hit and kicked me multiple times in my gut legs, kneecaps, neck, face and forhead. At this time I thought I was going to die I was bloody and bruised and in pain. So my training kicked in and next thing I knew I saw red and broke free of the other 2 and lunged at my attacker. I we both slammed the deck and I hit him multiple times shattering his jaw in 3 places including his hinge joint but this at the time I didnt know. He screamed and finally the other 2 guys pulled me off of him as I was clawing at him like some kind of animal.
 
 Next my flight instict kicked in and I broke free again and bolted out the door to the next deck up to the master of arms office and told what happnened. 3 of the individuals were arrested the other who I hit spent a month in the infirmary drinking from a straw. Mind you I'm not a violent person what soeverand was shaking after what happened. So I was transfered off the ship to a shore command where now I am awaiting seperation from the Navy due to mental stress and fear of ever going back to a ship again. The four individuals were court mashalled and disonorably discharged with a hate crime and are now branded as felons.

 This is entirely reasonable, and expectable for a variety of reasons...
 Obviously some of you will read the following and think "Duh!", cause you already know and realize this.
 But others like Archie obviously can't fathom how other people can think another person is "gay" without being told...
 
 I am gay. I joined the Navy as an officer.
 Inquiring minds wanted to know things about me and asked simple questions. 
 Was I married? Did I have a girl-friend? What did I do when we went to Pattaya? Did I sleep with one of the local prostitutes? Why didn't I sleep with one of the local prostitutes? What sex stories do I have?
 yadda, yadda, yadda...
 
 This is real life here. Some of those questions are obviously a little "racy", but obviously there are watered down versions.
 A gay person has a few options to address this.
 1) He can tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth. He outs himself. He risks separation from the military.
 No matter how many of his fellow military members do not have a problem with it, all it takes is one person in the chain of command, or another peer with enough aggression to try to get him kicked out, and your job is gone.
 2) He can lie. Invent a wife or a girl-friend or ___. Or possibly find a military lesbian and they can marry, providing each other with a cover story.
 3) He can answer as much truth without explicitly outing himself. No, I'm not married. No, I don't have a girlfriend. No, I didn't hook up while we were in port. No, I'm not going to share my sexual history with you.
 Of course, such an approach provides separation from the person and his peers. And it doesn't stop the speculation. It doesn't stop follow on questions like "why don't you have a girl-friend?" "Do you think that girl is hot?" "Why don't you go talk to her?"
 
 There are plenty of gay people out there who want to serve their country, but catering to homophobes makes it difficult for them to show their patriotism. I got out when I realized that I could serve for close to 20 years, but risk losing my entire pension if anybody "outed" me.
